properties.name: End of French and Indian War
properties.description: The French and Indian War concluded with France's defeat in 1763, an outcome that unexpectedly marked the beginning of significant colonial discontent as Great Britain, despite colonial support in the war, initiated new policies.

properties.name: British Imposition of Post-War Policies
properties.description: Following the French and Indian War, the British Parliament imposed new taxes to help compensate for substantial wartime costs and simultaneously transferred control of the colonies' western lands to British officials in Montreal, fundamentally altering the colonial relationship.

properties.name: Stamp Act Congress Convenes
properties.description: Representatives from several colonies assembled the Stamp Act Congress in 1765, where they drafted the 'Declaration of Rights and Grievances,' a document asserting that new British taxation policies imposed without colonial representation fundamentally violated their inherent rights as Englishmen.

properties.name: Boston Tea Party
properties.description: On December 16, 1773, a pivotal escalation in the American Revolution occurred when Sons of Liberty activists, disguised as Native Americans, boarded British East India Company ships in Boston Harbor and defiantly dumped chests of tea into the water.

properties.name: Passage of Intolerable Acts
properties.description: In response to the Boston Tea Party, London enacted a series of punitive laws, collectively known as the Intolerable Acts, which effectively terminated self-government in Massachusetts and closed Boston Harbor, though these measures paradoxically intensified the revolutionary cause.

properties.name: First Continental Congress Convenes
properties.description: In late 1774, twelve of the Thirteen Colonies dispatched delegates to the First Continental Congress in Philadelphia, establishing a unified forum for deliberation and collective action to coordinate Patriot resistance, notably by organizing a boycott of all British goods enforced by local committees.

properties.name: Battles of Lexington and Concord (Start of Revolutionary War)
properties.description: On April 19, 1775, the American Revolutionary War was officially launched with the Battles of Lexington and Concord, marking the culmination of ideological and political movements and the beginning of open armed conflict between the British and colonial forces.

properties.name: Declaration of Independence Adoption
properties.description: On July 4, 1776, the Second Continental Congress unanimously adopted the Declaration of Independence, a document primarily authored by Thomas Jefferson that formally rejected monarchy and aristocracy, embraced liberalism and republicanism, and famously declared 'all men are created equal,' escalating the war.

properties.name: Treaty of Paris and US Independence
properties.description: The war officially concluded with the signing of the Treaty of Paris on September 3, 1783, which formally acknowledged the independence of the United States of America from Great Britain and granted the new nation vast territories, establishing the world's first constitutional republic.

properties.name: Shift from Salutary Neglect Causes Discontent
properties.description: The significant change in British policy from 'salutary neglect' to direct control and taxation after the French and Indian War caused profound colonial discontent and a desire for greater autonomy because colonists had grown accustomed to self-governance and viewed the new policies as an infringement on their established practices and rights.

properties.name: Taxation Without Representation Causes Rebellion
properties.description: British Parliament's imposition of direct taxes, particularly the Stamp Act, without colonial representation, directly caused widespread colonial protest and the formation of unified resistance efforts, as it was perceived by colonists as a violation of their fundamental rights as Englishmen.

properties.name: Punitive Measures Escalate Revolutionary Cause
properties.description: London's punitive responses to colonial protests, such as the Intolerable Acts enacted after the Boston Tea Party, unintentionally served to expand and intensify the revolutionary cause by effectively ending self-government in Massachusetts and uniting other colonies against perceived British tyranny.

properties.source_text_quote: Discontent with colonial rule began shortly after the defeat of France in the French and Indian War in 1763. Even though the colonies had fought in and supported the war, British Parliament imposed new taxes to compensate for wartime costs and turned control of the colonies' western lands over to the British officials in Montreal.
properties.reasoning: The end of the war is explicitly stated as the temporal trigger for British policy changes and subsequent colonial discontent.

properties.source_text_quote: In 1764 Parliament passed the Sugar Act, decreasing the existing customs duties on sugar and molasses but providing stricter measures of enforcement and collection. That same year, Grenville proposed direct taxes on the colonies to raise revenue... Parliament passed the Stamp Act in March 1765... Representatives from several colonies convened the Stamp Act Congress in 1765.
properties.reasoning: The new taxes, particularly the Stamp Act, directly led to the convening of the Stamp Act Congress to address grievances.

properties.source_text_quote: Representatives from several colonies convened the Stamp Act Congress in 1765; its 'Declaration of Rights and Grievances' argued that taxation without representation violated their rights as Englishmen.
properties.reasoning: The Congress's declaration directly articulates the mechanism of 'taxation without representation' causing grievances, a core part of Hypothesis 2.

properties.source_text_quote: Even though the colonies had fought in and supported the war, British Parliament imposed new taxes to compensate for wartime costs and turned control of the colonies' western lands over to the British officials in Montreal.
properties.reasoning: This event describes the policy shift from salutary neglect, which is the triggering condition for Hypothesis 1, although it doesn't explicitly state the *reason* for the colonial discontent.

properties.source_text_quote: On December 16, 1773, ... Sons of Liberty activists ... instigated the Boston Tea Party, during which they boarded and dumped chests of tea ... into Boston Harbor. London responded by closing Boston Harbor and enacting a series of punitive laws, which effectively ended self-government in Massachusetts...
properties.reasoning: The text explicitly states that London's response (Intolerable Acts) was 'in response' to the Boston Tea Party.

properties.source_text_quote: The British government responded by passing four laws that came to be known as the Intolerable Acts, further darkening colonial opinion towards England. In response, Massachusetts patriots issued the Suffolk Resolves and formed an alternative shadow government... In September 1774, the First Continental Congress convened, consisting of representatives from each colony, to serve as a vehicle for deliberation and collective action.
properties.reasoning: The Intolerable Acts are presented as leading to the increased unity and coordination seen in the First Continental Congress.

properties.source_text_quote: The First Continental Congress began coordinating Patriot resistance through underground networks of committees. ... It also began coordinating Patriot resistance by militias which existed in every colony and which had gained military experience in the French and Indian War. For the first time, the Patriots were armed and unified against Parliament. Following the Battles of Lexington and Concord, Washington and the Continental Army responded by surrounding Boston...
properties.reasoning: The Congress's coordination of resistance and militias laid the groundwork for the armed conflict that began at Lexington and Concord.

properties.source_text_quote: The revolution culminated in the American Revolutionary War, which was launched on April 19, 1775, in the Battles of Lexington and Concord. Leaders of the American Revolution were colonial separatist leaders who... came to embrace the cause of full independence... The Second Continental Congress... unanimously adopted the Declaration of Independence the following year, which inspired, formalized, and escalated the war.
properties.reasoning: The outbreak of full-scale war pushed the Second Continental Congress towards formally declaring independence.

properties.source_text_quote: On July 4, 1776, they unanimously adopted the Declaration of Independence... The Revolutionary War continued for another five years during which France ultimately entered the war, supporting the colonial cause of independence. ... leading to the collapse of King George's control of Parliament and consensus in Parliament that the war should be ended on American terms. On September 3, 1783, the British signed the Treaty of Paris, granting their former colonies nearly all the territory...
properties.reasoning: The Declaration formalized and escalated the war, which eventually led to the Treaty of Paris acknowledging independence.

properties.source_text_quote: Discontent with colonial rule began shortly after the defeat of France in the French and Indian War in 1763.

British Parliament imposed new taxes to compensate for wartime costs and turned control of the colonies' western lands over to the British officials in Montreal. In 1764 Parliament passed the Sugar Act...

Representatives from several colonies convened the Stamp Act Congress in 1765; its 'Declaration of Rights and Grievances' argued that taxation without representation violated their rights as Englishmen.

On December 16, 1773, in a seminal event in the American Revolution's escalation, Sons of Liberty activists wearing costumes of Native Americans instigated the Boston Tea Party, during which they boarded and dumped chests of tea owned by the British East India Company into Boston Harbor.

London responded by closing Boston Harbor and enacting a series of punitive laws, which effectively ended self-government in Massachusetts but also served to expand and intensify the revolutionary cause.

In late 1774, 12 of the Thirteen Colonies sent delegates to the First Continental Congress, which met inside Carpenters' Hall in Philadelphia; the Province of Georgia joined in 1775. The First Continental Congress began coordinating Patriot resistance through underground networks of committees.
The revolution culminated in the American Revolutionary War, which was launched on April 19, 1775, in the Battles of Lexington and Concord.

On July 4, 1776, they unanimously adopted the Declaration of Independence, authored primarily by Thomas Jefferson, which embodied the political philosophies of liberalism and republicanism, rejected monarchy and aristocracy, and famously proclaimed that 'all men are created equal'.
On September 3, 1783, the British signed the Treaty of Paris, granting their former colonies nearly all the territory east of the Mississippi River and south of the Great Lakes.

After the Revolution, one colonist, Capt. Levi Preston, of Danvers, Massachusetts, was asked why the Americans rebelled against England, responded, '…we always had governed ourselves, and we always meant to. They didn’t mean we should.'

According to historian Robert Middlekauff, 'Americans had become almost completely self-governing' before the American Revolution, a practice that was consistent with the British monarchy's practice of salutary neglect.

Representatives from several colonies convened the Stamp Act Congress in 1765; its 'Declaration of Rights and Grievances' argued that taxation without representation violated their rights as Englishmen.

The colonists did not object that the taxes were high; they were actually low. ...They objected to their lack of representation in the Parliament, which gave them no voice concerning legislation that affected them, such as the tax, violating the unwritten English constitution. This grievance was summarized in the slogan 'No taxation without representation'.

Shortly following adoption of the Stamp Act, the Sons of Liberty formed, and began using public demonstrations, boycotts, and threats of violence to ensure that the British tax laws became unenforceable. ...Congress emphasized their determination by organizing a boycott on imports of all British merchandise.

London responded by closing Boston Harbor and enacting a series of punitive laws, which effectively ended self-government in Massachusetts but also served to expand and intensify the revolutionary cause.
The British government responded by passing four laws that came to be known as the Intolerable Acts, further darkening colonial opinion towards England.

In late 1774, 12 of the Thirteen Colonies sent delegates to the First Continental Congress, which met inside Carpenters' Hall in Philadelphia... Congress called for a boycott beginning on December 1, 1774, of all British goods; it was enforced by new local committees authorized by the Congress. It also began coordinating Patriot resistance by militias...
